metadata.case_name: Pooran Mal & Ganeriwala v. Director of Inspection & Ors. (Writ Petitions Nos. 446/1971 & 86/1972; Civil Appeals Nos. 1319 & 1320/1968)
metadata.case_number: Writ Petition Nos. 446 of 1971 and 86 of 1972; Civil Appeals Nos. 1319 and 1320 of 1968

facts.text: Searches and seizures conducted under section 132 of Income-tax Act, 1961 in four cases: account books, documents, cash, jewelry and valuables seized.
Civil Appeals from Delhi High Court judgment dated 22nd March 1968 in Writ Petitions Nos. 798-D and 800-D of 1966; documents returned before High Court disposal.

Writ Petition 446/1971: Pooran Mal, partner in firms in Bombay and Delhi; residence at 12A Kamla Nagar, Delhi searched 15-16 Oct 1971; business premises A/14/16 Jamuna Bhavan searched; Rs. 61,000 cash, jewelry Rs.37,043, documents seized; 84 silver bars from Laxmi Commercial Bank, 30 from Punjab National Bank (value ~18 lakhs).
Pooran Mal searches also at Bombay premises on 15 Oct 1971; petitioner present there.
ITO summary enquiry under s.132(5) on 12-1-1972; retained assets except ornaments declared in Wealth Tax Return against tax dues ~42 lakhs from 1969 onwards.
Pooran Mal assessments pending 1967-68; no returns 1968-69 onwards; uncooperative per department chart.

Writ Petition 86/1972: Ganeriwala, businessman, residence 1 Raj Narain Road, Civil Lines, Delhi; business Ganeriwala Trading Co. at 1 Krishna Motor Market searched 8 Oct 1971 from 8 AM to evening; books, documents seized; no cash/bullion/jewelry found; new godown constructed ~6700 sq ft.
Ganeriwala assessments completed up to 1970-71 income, 1969-70 wealth; return filed 1970-71.
Director of Inspection recorded reasons before authorisations; grounds satisfied for belief under s.132(1)(a)(b)(c).
Petitioners alleged mala fides, oppression: search on Dhanteras, despite requests to postpone, unknown panchas, long duration, seized children's money/jewelry of deceased; denied by department.

legal_issues.text: Whether sub-sections (1) and (5) of section 132 of Income-tax Act, 1961 and rule 112A violate Articles 14, 19(1)(f)(g) and 31 of Constitution.
Whether searches and seizures complied with section 132 and rule 112.
Whether evidence from illegal search/seizure can be used in proceedings.

petitioner_arguments.text: Authorisation, search and seizure illegal; non-compliance with s.132 and rule 112; mala fides, oppression, excessive.
Provisions violative of Arts 14,19(1)(f)(g),31: unreasonable restrictions, arbitrary belief by Director, confiscatory, discriminates evaders with/without undisclosed assets.
Director incapable of reasonable belief under s.132(1)(b); only after failed summons.
Evidence from illegal search inadmissible; writ of prohibition against use.

respondent_arguments.text: Safeguards in s.132 adequate: high officers, recorded reasons, specific purposes, CrPC applies, time-limits for retention/release, interest on excess.
Director has access to info via hierarchy ss.116-120,135; can form belief on undisclosed income info.
No discrimination under Art.14; s.132 for cases where search useful to recover undisclosed assets.
Evidence admissible if relevant, regardless of illegal search; Indian Evidence Act s.5.
Searches proper; allegations denied; panchas respectable; books not seized if irrelevant.

court_reasoning.text: Power of search/seizure reasonable restriction under Art.19(1)(f)(g) for preventing tax evasion; safeguards mirror CrPC; vested in high officers, requires belief, specific, time-bound retention/release.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Drastic measures justified against tax evaders; adequate safeguards render restrictions reasonable.

court_reasoning.text: Director can form reasonable belief under s.132(1)(b) based on info of concealed deals despite past compliance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Illustration: honest assessee investing undisclosed funds; likely non-production if summoned.

court_reasoning.text: S.132(5) not confiscatory: summary provisional estimate; regular assessment follows; excess returned with 9% interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sequestration to secure dues; not substitute for assessment.

court_reasoning.text: No Art.14 violation: different situations; search only where useful; same assessment procedure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evaders without traceable assets not comparable class.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence from illegal search admissible if relevant; no constitutional bar; follows English/Indian law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Relevancy sole test under Evidence Act s.5; cannot import US exclusionary rule.

court_reasoning.text: Searches in WPs valid: grounds for belief exist; allegations of mala fides unsubstantiated; procedure followed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finding undisclosed assets supports belief; no illegality.

holdings.text: Sections 132(1),(5), 132A and rules 112,112A constitutional; not violative of Arts 14,19(1)(f)(g),31.
Searches and seizures in all cases legal; complied with s.132, rule 112.
Information/evidence from search/seizure (even if illegal) usable in IT proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: M. P. Sharma v. Satish Chandra
precedents_cited.relevance: Search/seizure overriding state power for social security; temporary interference; not violative of Art.19(1)(f).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Commercial Taxes v. R. S. Jhaver
precedents_cited.relevance: Search/seizure in taxing statutes valid to check evasion if CrPC safeguards.

precedents_cited.case_name: A. K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Courts cannot invoke 'spirit' of Constitution to strike down law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Balwant Singh v. Director of Inspection

precedents_cited.relevance: Relevancy test for admissibility; irrelevant how obtained.
Relevant evidence admissible despite illegal search.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of search/seizure, belief conditions, summary enquiry, retention/release of assets, regular assessment.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior summons/notices for belief under s.132(1)(a)(b).

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Applies to searches under s.132(1); safeguards.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Rules, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for search/seizure and enquiry under s.132(5).

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenges to s.132; no bar to evidence from illegal search.

outcome.summary: Two writ petitions under Art.32 and two appeals from Delhi HC dismissed; s.132 etc. upheld as constitutional; searches valid; evidence usable even if search illegal; all with costs.

key_quotes.text: "A power of search and seizure is in any system of jurisprudence an overriding power of the State for the protection of social security and that power is necessarily regulated by law."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The test to be applied... is whether it is relevant to the matters in issue. If it is, it is admissible and the court is not concerned with how it was obtained."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Admissibility of evidence from illegal search (Kuruma).

key_quotes.text: "Courts are not at liberty to declare an Act void because in their opinion it is opposed to a spirit supposed to pervade the Constitution but not expressed in words."
key_quotes.speaker: court
